key_insight: Incorporating neural network connectivity into a self-supervised learning framework yields compact, label-free representations of neuronal activity that enable high-content screening to identify genetic modifiers of activity dynamics.
problem_solved: Traditional phenotypic screens for neuronal dynamics require extensive labels, ignore network topology, and struggle to detect subtle, distributed effects of genetic perturbations—this work provides a scalable, label-free way to detect and compare phenotypes across interventions.
method: Network-aware self-supervised representation learning that fuses temporal activity patterns with connectivity information to produce discriminative embeddings.
Contrastive or predictive SSL objectives applied to time-series recordings (e.g., calcium/electrophysiology) to learn phenotypic signatures without manual labels.
High-throughput screening pipeline mapping genetic perturbations to changes in embedding space, enabling clustering, hit-calling, and comparison across interventions.
impact: Provides ML practitioners with a template for building label-efficient, topology-aware models for biological dynamics, enabling scalable discovery of genetic modifiers and transferable phenotypic embeddings for downstream analysis.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: raw neural recordings + connectivity → network-aware SSL model → low-dimensional phenotypic embeddings → hit identification
Example time-series and activity raster plots showing pre/post perturbation dynamics
Embedding visualization (UMAP/t-SNE) colored by genetic perturbation to show phenotypic clusters and outliers
Heatmap or perturbation-response matrix summarizing effect sizes of genetic modifiers across measured features
paper_title: Network-aware self-supervised learning enables high-content phenotypic screening for genetic modifiers of neuronal activity dynamics
paper_authors: Parker Grosjean, Kaivalya Shevade, Cuong Nguyen, Sarah Ancheta, Karl Mader
